title: SAFE Act dilemma involving 'assault' rifles
text:
SAFE Act dilemma involving 'assault' rifles DAVE HENDERSON, Correspondent 7:30 a.m. EDT October 10, 2015 Tactial AR15 M4 Variant Rifle (Photo: RiseAboveDesign / Getty Images / iStockphoto) 139 CONNECT 24 TWEET LINKEDIN 8 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
There were AR-15 rifles, known in New York as “assault weapons,” openly on sale at last month’s Syracuse Gun Show at the state fairgrounds, despite the state’s prohibition on sales of such weapons. 
The guns featured, it should be noted, were legal because they were altered by $15 stock adjusters that skirted the SAFE Act description of that constitutes an assault weapon. 
The New York State Rifle and Pistol Association has estimated that there are between 900,000 and a million "assault weapons" in the state, but one has to think that only a few thousand have been altered to be legal. 
What about the rest? The SAFE Act mandated that all such weapons had to be registered by April 2014 and could not be sold or transferred within the state. 
The compliance date came and went with little fanfare, and this past June the state was forced by a lawsuit to admit that just 44,485 have been registered. 
That number, hidden from the public for more than a year by state officials, was given to Rochester-area lawyer Paloma Capanna in response to a lawsuit she filed on behalf of radio host Bill Robinson. 
The state contended that the contents of the registration database is exempt from public disclosure, but Capanna argued that it should be public information, like handgun licenses. 
That means that somewhere between 95 and 97 percent of the state’s “assault weapons” owners have not registered their guns and are thus liable for felony charges. What is being done about it? 
A better question is what can be done? The state has no way of knowing who owns the affected guns, or how many. 
The state can either continue to ignore the situation or repeal that aspect of the SAFE Act. Fat chance of that. 
One has to guess that there will be some kind of negotiations that will allow the state to save face. 
Groton maintains trap lead 
Scott Batzer and Don Nickerson both turned in perfect scores at Trumansburg last week to lead their Groton team to a 245 total, keeping it two birds ahead of the field after two weeks of the Cayuga Lake Trap League 
Dryden’s John Stanley and Newfield’s Ted Labar had the only other 50s among the 124 shooters who took part. Newfield tied Groton for high team score of 245, and Dryden shot 244 to maintain second place in the standings. 
Mark Patton of Dryden broke 48, keeping him in a tie for the league individual lead with Stanley and Batzer at 98. 
Youth pheasant hunt 
Organizer Larry Shutts notes that there are still a couple of openings for this weekend’s Youth Pheasant Hunt, sponsored by the Conservation Alliance of New York. 
Licensed 12- to 15-year-old hunters who can be accompanied by a non-hunting adult are eligible for the hunt, which will be held at the Molyneau Tree Farm on Sherder Road, off Route 38B between Newark Valley and Endicott. 
Anyone interested should contact Shutts at (607) 642-8609. 
Wolves act canceled 
Wolves of the World, one of the primary wildlife acts for this weekend’s ninth annual Southern Tier Outdoor Show in Bath, has canceled due to an emergency in the exhibitor’s family. 
Eagle falconry will put on two shows to help fill the schedule, and Maxman Reptile Rescue has agreed to fill in with three shows daily. 
Henderson's outdoors columns appear Thursday and his Field Notes columns on Sunday. Write to him at Henderson Outdoors (www.HendersonOutdoors.com), 202 Prospect St, Endicott NY 13760 or via e-mail at ddhender@aol.com. 139 CONNECT 24 TWEET LINKEDIN 8 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://ithacajr.nl/1Lit8Lw TOP VIDEOS
